title: American_Top_40_1975_April_19th
description:
"From the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of Alaska, you hear the nation's biggest hits every week at this time on American Top 40. My name is Casey Kasem."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is a rebroadcast from internet radio. 

In this countdown:

A chart first. The oldest recording ever to make the top 40, a recording made 29 years before this countdown, has its debut.

A listener wants to know, "What song was on the chart the most weeks in a row without ever hitting number one?" Casey says it was also the song that was on the chart the most weeks in a row period; a record 39 weeks in 1957.

John Lennon is at number 24 with his remake of a song by Ben E. King, "Stand By Me" and ironically, Ben E. King is back on the chart after a 12 year absence with his hit, "Supernatural Thing" (at number 6).

Paul Anka is on the chart with his 43rd top 40 hit, "I Don't Like To Sleep Alone" (at number 17).

Casey tells the story of the most popular suicide song ever written, the Hungarian Suicide Song, a song whose composer took his own life.

Only one artist was able to keep a record at number 1 for more than a week in 1975 until this countdown, the same artist whose doing it here.
